contentrichtext.text: In [[set theory]], a '''supercompact cardinal''' is a type of [[large cardinal]]. They display a variety of reflection properties. ==Formal definition== If λ is any [[ordinal number|ordinal]], κ is '''λ-supercompact''' means that there exists an elementary embedding ''j'' from the universe ''V'' into a transitive [[inner model]] ''M'' with [[critical point (set theory)|critical point]] κ, ''j''(κ)>λ and :<math>{ }^\lambda M\subseteq M \,.</math> That is, ''M'' contains all of its λ-sequences. Then κ is '''supercompact''' means that it is λ-supercompact for all ordinals λ. Alternatively, an uncountable cardinal κ is '''supercompact''' if for every ''A'' such that |''A''| â‰¥ κ there exists a [[normal measure]] over [''A'']<sup>< κ</sup>. [''A'']<sup>< κ</sup> is defined as follows: :<math>[A]^{< \kappa} := \{X \subseteq A| |X| < \kappa\} \,.</math> ==Properties== Supercompact cardinals have reflection properties. If a cardinal with some property (say a 3-[[huge cardinal]]) that is witnessed by a structure of limited rank exists above a supercompact cardinal κ, then a cardinal with that property exists below κ. For example, if κ is supercompact and the [[Generalized Continuum Hypothesis]] holds below κ then it holds everywhere because a bijection between the powerset of ν and a cardinal at least ν<sup>++</sup> would be a witness of limited rank for the failure of GCH at ν so it would also have to exist below κ. Finding a canonical inner model for supercompact cardinals is one of the major problems of [[inner model theory]]. ==References== * {{cite book|author=Drake, F.
